questions.text: Shortly after delivery, a full-term male newborn is found to have black hair with a white forelock. His mother, a brunette, auditory brainstem auditory evoked responses show bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely cause of findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Waardenburg syndrome is a rare disease characterized by deafness in association with pigmentary anomalies and defects of neural crest-derived tissues.
Features-

  • Lateral displacement of the medial canthus combined with dystopia of the lacrimal puncta and blepharophimosis
  • Prominent broad nasal root
  • Hypertrichosis of the medial part of the eyebrows
  • White forelock
  • Heterochromia iridis
  • Deafmutism

questions.text: A 51 -year-old woman undergoes coronary angiography for chest pain. Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) performed in the emergency department shows ST elevation in leads VI,V3. Angiography findings are shown in this image. Which of the following best describes the findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
This patient's presentation of chest pain and ST elevation in leads Vl-V3 on electrocardiogram (ECG) are consistent with ST elevation myocardial infarction due to occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD). These coronary angiogram Images reveal an area of severe stenosis (red arrows) in the proximal LAD due to atherosclerotic plaque.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of fever, chills, and dyspnea on exertion. He admits to smoking one pack of cigarettes a day, consuming 2-3 alcoholic beverages daily, and using intravenous illicit drugs 2-3 times per week. He is febrile and tachycardic. Blood cultures grow Staphylococcus aureus. A diagnosis of infective endocarditis is established. The valve most likely affected in this patient can be best evaluated by auscultation in which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Right-sided endocarditis involving the tricuspid valve commonly occurs in IV drug users and is most often due to Staphylococcus eu us. Specifically, infective endocarditis can cause tricuspid regurgitation, which is identified as an early systolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border that is accentuated by inspiration.
Heart sounds/murmurs result from reverberation of blood secondary to valve closure. Auscultation to determine function of a valve is performed at the position closest to where the sound waves reverberate and not at the position of the valve.

questions.text: A 42-year old man comes to the office with rectal bleeding. He used to have occasional streaks of blood on the tissue after wiping but for the past several days he has seen blood dipping into the toilet bowl at the end of defecation. The patient gives a history of chronic constipation and has to strain during defecation but has na rectal or abdominal pain. He works as a truck driver and his diet consists mainly of unhealthy foods. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. There is no mass or tenderness on digital rectal examination, but anoscopy shows bulging purplish-blue mucosal lesions above the dentate line. Rubber band ligation of the lesions is most likely to involve which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Hemorrhoids are classified based on their relation to the dentate line in the anal canal, with Internal hemorrhoids originating above the line and external hemorrhoids below. They result from distension into the canal of one of several arterlovenous plexuses (anal cushions), which are composed of vascular tissue, smooth muscle, and connective tissue. The venous component of internal hemorrhoids drains into the middle and superior rectal veins, which communicate with the internal iliac and Inferior mesenteric veins, respectively. Extemal hemorrhoids drain via the inferior rectal vein into the internal pudendal vein, which communicates with the internal iliac veins.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department after the sudden onset af shortness of breath and difficulty swallowing. He has visited the emergency department several times before for food and skin allergies. He is unconscious on Examination shows excessive accessory respiratory muscle use and edematous swelling of his face. lips, and tongue. There is scattered urticaria over his upper body. Attempts at intubation are unsuccessful due the massive soft tissue edema involving his pharynx. A decision is made to perform an emergency cricothyrotomy. The incision made during this procedure will most likely pass through which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
This patient is experiencing acute, life-threatening laryngeal edema as part of an anaphylactic reaction precipitated by exposure to an allergen. Laryngeal edema can inhale present with throat tightness, dtfncutty swallowing, dyspnea, and hoarseness. However, the condition can quickly progress to compromise airway and cause asphyxiation.
Cricothyrotomy is indicated when an emergency airway is required and orotracheal or nasotracheal intubation is either unsuccessful or contraindicated (eg, due to massive hemorrhage, vomiting, facial trauma, " airway obstruction). The procedure establishes an airway through the placement of a tube between the cricoid and thyroid cartilages and requires an incision hough the following structures:
1 . Skin
 2. Superficial cervical fascia (including subcutaneous fat and platysma muscle)
 3. Investing and pretracheal layers of the deep cervical fascia
 4. Cricothyroid membrane

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after falling from a chair onto an outstretched arm. Her mother believes that she hyperextended her arm. Physical examination shows swelling of the right elbow and tenderness to palpation over the distal humerus. Radial pulses are full and symmetric bilaterally. The patient is unable to cooperate with neurologic examination of the right hand du. to significant pain. A peripheral intravenous line is placed and opiate analgesics are administered for pain control. X-rays show a supracondylar humeral fracture with anterolateral displacement of the proximal fracture fragment. Which of the following structures is at greatest risk for injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Supracondylar humeral fractures are common pediatric elbow fractures that often occur after hyperflexion or hyperextension injuries (eg, falling onto an outstretched arm). These fractures carry a significant risk of neurovascular compromise, particularly if the fracture is displaced.Radial nerve is injured the most.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with seven right hip pain after a fall. She was walking down a hallway when she pipped on a rug and fell against a wall and then to the floor, landing on her hip. The patient has a history of depression and Polymyalgia rheumatica. Current medications include sertraline and low-dose prednisone. She also has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg and pulse is 96/min. The patient appears to be in significant pain. She is unable to move the right hip, and the right leg appears shorter than the left. A pelvic x-ray is shown in the image below:

Injury involving which of the following arteries is most likely to lead to osteonecrosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
This patient's x-ray shows a right femoral neck fracture, which is common in elderly patients with osteoporosis who have sustained a fall. Femoral neck fractures, especially when displaced, put the femoral head at risk for osteonecrosis if its blood supply is disrupted. The blood supply to the femoral head derives mainly from the ascending cervical and retinacular branches of the medial circumflex artery. These vessels are especially vulnerable to damage from fractures of the femoral neck due to their close association with it.

questions.text: A 29-year-old previously healthy man comes to the hospital wtUI a right leg injury acer a cycling accident. He reports pain in the lower log and inability to bear weight. X-ray reveals right Tibial and fibular shaft fractures. The parent undergoes closed reduction and immobilization of he fractures. Several hours later. he has increasingly severe pain in his right leg. Physical examination shows increased tension within the anterior compartment. Which of the following structures is most likely to be compromised by this parent's acute complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The deep fascia of the leg. the fascia intermuscular septae, and the interosseous membrane divides the leg into 4 compartments (anterior, lateral, and superficial and deep posterior). The fascia is inelastic and limits outward expansion of the contracting muscles. If the pressure in a compartment increases. The circulation within c8n become compromised, leading to severe pain and eventual tissue Ischemia. This complication. acute compartment syndrome (ACS), can be due to long-bone fractures, crash injury, hemel injury. ornontraumatic causes (eg, bleeding disorders, vascular disease). Early diagnosis and Surgical decompression (fasciotomy) af the invdvnd compartments are necessary to prevent permanent and disabling injury (eg, myonecrosis, nerve damage, amputation)-
 The most common sRe for ACS is the anterior compartment of the leg. which includes the foot extensor muscles, anterior tibial artery, and the deep peroneal (Fibular) neue. Injury to the deep peroneal neue causes decreased sensation between the first and second toes, decreased dorsiflexion of the foot, foot drop, and claw foot[Choice B) The great (long) saphenous vein starts in the donum of dte foot and runs along the medial leg and anterior thigh before merging with The common femoral vein in the femoral triangle. It is outside the deep fascia and is not vulnerable to ACS.

questions.text: Cultured fibroblasts taken from an infant suffering from hypotonia and seizures show an Impaired ability to oxidize very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) and phytanic acid. The detect is most likely localized to:?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
The patient described in the question stem is most likely suffering from a peroxisomal disease. Peroxisomal diseases are rare inborn errors of metabolism where peroxisomes are either absent or nonfunctional. Very long chain and some branched chain fatty acids cannot undergo mitochondrial beta-oxidation. These fatty acids are metabolized by a specialfomi of beta oxidation (very long chain fatty acids) or by alpha oxidation  (branched chain fatty acids such as phytanic acid) when peroxisomes, When peroxisomes are absent or nonfunctional. these fatty acids accumulate within the tissues. One example of a peroxisomal disease is Zellweger syndrome. In this condition, infants are unable to properly fomi myelin in the CNS. Symptoms of this disease include hypotonia and seizures as mentioned in the question stem as well as hepatomegaly, mental retardation. andeartv death within months of Initial presentation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is hospitalized with headaches and vomiting. She has a long history of psychiatric illness and known to practice eccentric dietary habits. Physical landings include papilledema, dry skin and hepatosplenomegaly. Head CT scan is ordered immediately but is negative for intracranial mass. Which of the following is a likely the cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Vitamin A toxicity has been subdivided Into three syndromes: acute. chronic, and teratogenic. The suns and symptoms of  toxicity occur after the Ingestion of a tingle high doses of vitamin A and Include nausea, vomhing, vertigo. and blurred asian.  The signs and symptoms of chronic toxicity occur attBr the long-term Ingestion of high doses of vitamin A. and Include alopecia. dry skin, hyperlipidemia, hepatotoxicity, hepatosplenomegaly, and visual difficulties. Papilledema. when present. Is suggestive of cerebral enema in the setting of benign Intracranial hypertension (pseudotumorcerebri)-  Teratogenic effects of excessive vitamin A Ingestion Include microcephaly, cardiac anomalous, and fetal death (e9oclalV in the ersttHmester of pregnancy).

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the neurologist for enrollment in a research study. She has a 15-year history of resting tremor. bradykinesia. and cogwheel rigidity cons-stent with Parkinson disease. One of her siblings recently started having similar symptoms. Genetic analysis is permitted on the patient and her affected sibling. The results show a loss-of-function mutation in a gene that leads to an accumulation of misfolded proteins. Which of the following biochemical processes is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Ubiquitin is a protein found in all eukaryotic cells Mat undergoes ATP-dependent attachment to other proteins. labeling them for degradation. The proteasome then recognizes these ubiquitinated proteins and uses ATP energy to drive them through its tubular structure, degrading them into small peptides in the process. Attachment of 4 0r more ubiquitin monomers is required before most proteins are allowed entry into the proteasome. Ubiquitination plays an important role in many cell functions, including antigen processing, muscle wasting, cell cycle regulation, DNA repair. and disposal of misfolded proteins and regulatory enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following blocks the enzyme complex II in the given figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: An 18.month-old boy is brought to the office due to language regression. He said several words at his 1 year appointment but now no longer speaks any words at all. His moods have also become more unpredictable over the past 4 months with frequent tantrums. The parents tried to bring him in sooner for evaluation, but they live in an unimproved shed part of the city and experienced financial difficulties with transportation to the office. On physical examination the boy is quiet and maintains appropriate eye Contact throughout the visit. Hemoglobin is 9 g/dl. Which of the following enzymes is most likely Inhibited in  hls patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
This child's language regression and anemia are most likely due to lead poisoning. I.ead toxicity is most prevalent among Impoverished children residing in deteriorating urban housing built before 1978. Young children are particularly susc-ptibla to lead poisoningvla Inhalation and Ingestion of lead-based paint dust or chips due to normal crawling and mouthing behaviors. The incomplete blood-brain-barrier in children is vulnerable to the neurotoxic effects of lead. which include long-standing behavioral problems and developmental delay or regression. Anemia in lead poisoning results from inhibition of 6-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthase, ALA dehydratase, and ferrochelatase in the heme biosynthesis pathway. Because protoporphyrin IX cannot Combine with iron (Fe") to form heme due to ferrochelatase inhibition, it Instead Incorporates a zinc ion, leading to elevated zinc protoporphyrin levels. In addition, ALA levels are increased. Lead poisoning also commonly coexists with Iron deficiency anemia, and severe lead poisoning can also

questions.text: A schematic structure of tRNA is shown on the slide below. Which of the following sites is responsible for amino acid binding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
tRNA is the smallest of the RNA subtypes. The Image above shows the tRNA secondary structure. The 3' and 5' ends of the molecule form the so-called 'acceptor stem.' The 3'end is the amino acid attachment site. The anticodon is located on the opposite end of thetRNA molecule (site C). It recognizes and binds the mRNA codon and assures placement of the proper amino acid in the growing polypeptide chain. The TWC amt, which contains a sequence of three nucleotides present in all tRNA molecules (ribothymidine, pseudouridine and cytosine) and the D loop have unpaired bases. The TWC arm. D tamp, and anticodon are responsible for The 'cloverleaf ' secondary structure of the molecule. The D and TWC loops help to determine the tRNA tertiary structure as well. The 5' end of tRNA generally is composed of a terminal guanosine and does not participate in amino acid or mRNA binding.

questions.text: A 35-year-old previously healthy man is evaluated for several episodes of syncope in the past 6 weeks. Physical examination is unremarkable. Echocardiogram shows no structural heart defect.An electrophysiologic study is performed during which catheters are passed into the patient's right and left atrium to record atrial electric potentials. Cardiac marker currently shows normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely earliest site of electric activation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
The cardiac conduction system consists of the sinoatrial (SA) node, atrioventricular (AV) node, bundle of His, Right and left bundle branches, and the Purkinje system (which directly activates the ventricular myocardium). In patients with normal sinus rhythm (as in this patient), the SA node acts as the dominant pacemaker site and is the site of earliest electrical activation. The SA node is a compact subepicardial structure that consists of specialized pacemaker cells located at the junction of theright atrium and superior vena cava.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is evaluated for episodic abdominal discomfort, bloating sensation, flatulence. and occasional diarrhea He has no blood in the stool or weight loss. The parent has avoided dairy products, but the symptoms did not improve. On examination, there is mild epigastric tenderness on deep palpation. Stool occult blood testing is positive. Histopathological evaluation of hyperemic mucosa seen during gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals hyperplasia of branched, tubular submucosal glands containing alkaline secretions. Which of the following areas is the most likely finding biopsy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
The integrity of the small intestinal mucosa depends on the complete and rapidneutralization of hydrochloric acid in gastric contents. This is accomplished by alkaline secretions from 2 primary sources:
Submucosal Brunner glands secrete copious amounts of alkaline mucus into the duodenum. These glands are most numerous at the pylorus but may be found intermittently up to the ampulla of Vater. The ducts of these glands pass through the muscularis mucosa and terminate in the mucosal crypts(crypt of Lieberkahn).The epithelial cells of the pancreatic ductules and ducts produce waterysecretions containing high concentrations of bicarbonate ions. The strongly alkaline pancreatic secretions are then emptied into the duodenum at the ampulla.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy experiences excessive bleeding following a tooth extraction. His Past medical history includes episodes of painful joint swelling from minor trauma. Physical examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen with a liver span of 10 cm. The spleen is not palpable. Laboratory results are as follows:

•    Bleeding time- 5 min

•    Activated partial thromboplastin- 25 sec

•    Prothrombin time- 23 sec

This patient most likely has a deficiency involving which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
This patient's hemarthrosis and excessive bleeding following tooth extraction are suggestive of a coagulopathy (ie, clotting factor deficiency). Coagulopathiesgenerally present with deep-tissue bleeding into joints, muscles, and subcutaneoustissue. In contrast, platelet defects typically manifest with mucocutaneousbleeding (eg. epistaxis, petechiae). The patient's laboratory results show a normalbleeding time, normal Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and a prolongedprothrombin time (PT). The normal bleeding time indicates adequate plateletfunction, and the normal aPTT indicates an intact intrinsic coagulation system.However, the prolonged PT indicates a defect in the extrinsic coagulationpathway. Therefore, the patient is most likely deficient in factor VII.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician with concerns about a "heart problem". He feels fine, but was told to see a physician after a heart murmur was detected during a wellness fair at work. Physical examination reveals a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex of the heart that radiates to the axilla. The remainder of his physical examination is normal. Which of the following is the best indicator of the severity of this patient's problem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Under most clinical circumstances, the etiology and severity of mitral regurgitation (MR) are best delineated by 2D and Doppler echocardiography.Among auscultatory findings, the best indicator of severe MR with left ventricular volume overload is the presence of an S3 gallop. In cases of severe MR, the left ventricular S3 gallop reflects an increased rate of left ventricular filling due to a largevolume of regurgitant flow re-entering the ventricle during mid diastole.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old comes to the physician with a 2-month history of exertional dyspnea and progressive lower extremity swelling. He also reports abdominal distension and decreased appetite. The patient has gained 4.5 kg over the last 2 months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and recurrent lung infections requiring prolonged antibiotic therapy. He has no history of coronary artery disease. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 1 5 years. He undergoes noninvasive cardiac testing followed by cardiac catheterization. A jugular venous pressure tracing is shown on the slide below.

The waveform indicated by the arrow most likely corresponds to which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because he and his wife have been unable to conceive for the last 2 years. They have no children. Infertility evaluation is begun, and laboratory studies show a low sperm count A more thorough evaluation elucidates a rare genetic abnormality that leads to permanently inactive FSH receptors. Which of the following substances most likely decreases in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pulsatile secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone from the hypothalamus stimulates the release of folliclestimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone(LH) from the gonadotroph cells in the anterior pituitary. LH stimulates the release oftestosterone from the Leydig cells in the interstitium of the testicles, and FSH stimulates the release of inhibin B from the Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubulesof the testicles. Testosterone and inhibin B induce negative feedback on LH andFSH production, respectively.

questions.text: Skeletal muscle biopsy is performed on a 1 7-year-old male with proximal muscle weakness. No abnormalities are found on light microscopy. Electron microscopy of The specimen reveals no T-tubules in some muscle fibers. Which of the following is The most likely consequence of the observed finding in the affected muscle cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
T-tubules are invaginations of the muscle cell membrane (sarcolemma). T-tubulesare therefore extensions of the extracellular space. They run perpendicular to thelong axis of the muscle fiber and lie in close proximity to extensions of thesarcoplasmic reticulum (terminal cisterns). In skeletal muscle one T-tubule contactstwo terminal systems forming a triad at the junction of the A-band and the l-band.

questions.text:
Scientists are attempting to study the specifics of kidney function in humans. They begin by studying the concentrations of various compounds along the length of the proximal tubules in human kidneys. They are able to measure the concentrations of several substances over the length of a proximal tubule. Tubular fluid/plasma ultrafiltration concentration ratios for several substances hey wore able to measure are shown on the slide below:

Which of the following substances are most likely to produce cures 2 and 4,respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Line 2 is indicative of the behavior of urea in the proximal tubular quid. Urea is freelyfiltered from the glomerular capillaries and about 52% is reabsorbed from the proximaltubule. Since its reabsorption is less than the reabsorption of water in the PCT, the TF/P ratio for urea will be > 1.0. Renal handling of urea varies throughout thedifferent tubular systems, but it is ultimately excreted in very high concentrations, as it is a waste product of metabolism. 
Line 4 represents the behavior of bicarbonate in the proximal tubule. 80% of bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule due to the activity of carbonic anhydrasewithin proximal tubular cells. This reabsorbing force causes the concentration ofbicarbonate to decrease as fluid runs along the proximal tubule.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics following a high-speed motor vehicle accident. Several attempts are made to resuscitate him but are unsuccessful. The patient had no significant past medical history and took no medications. He was known to be in good health and tolerant of moderate levels of physical activity. Electrocardiogram findings at his last office visit showed no abnormalities. At autopsy, heavy calcifications of the aortic valve are seen as shown in the image. Which of the following most likely preceded the aortic valve changes observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
This patient's aortic valve calcifications most likely represent dystrophic calcification affecting an aging aortic valve. Dystrophic calcification is considered a hallmark of cell injury and death, occurring in all types of necrosis (eg, coagulative, fat, caseous, liquefactive) in the setting of normal calcium levels. Grossly, dystrophic calcium deposits are seen as fine, gritty, white granules or clumps. On hematoxylin and eosin staining, sese deposits typically appear as dark-purple, sharp-edged aggregates. Deposits that develop lamellated outer layers are described as psammoma bodies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a 1-week history of malaise,red eyes, swelling of his ankles, and red, tender nodules on the shins. He is not receiving any medications and has no prior medical or surgical history. On examination he has a temperature of 39°C, the skin findings shown in the illustration, synovitis of both ankles, and red eyes. Laboratory examination includes the chest radiographic findings shown below. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The patient has sarcoidosis, specifically Lfgren syndrome: the association of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar or right paratracheal lymphadenopathy. Erythema nodosum presents with red, tender nodules on the anterior aspect of the shins and is a hypersensitivity reaction to an antigenic exposure. Although most cases of erythema nodosum are idiopathic, acute sarcoidosis is a fairly common association. Lfgren syndrome is a marker for acute and benign sarcoidosis. In more than 80% of cases, the condition resolves spontaneously in 2 years. Important potential associations with ery- themanodosum include inflammatory bowel disease, drugs (oral contraceptives, sulfonamides), sarcoidosis, infection (Streptococcus,coccidioidomycosis, histoplasmosis, tuberculosis, Yersinia enterocolitica), and lymphoma. Therapy of erythema nodosum include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and potassium iodide and treatment of any associated underlying disease.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents for evaluation of recent onset of fatigue and weakness. She has noted difficulty doing her usual activities but is not very specific about this. On examination,she has the constellation of skin findings shown in the illustrations and some mild upper extremity weakness. Which tumor is most likely associated with this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Dermatomyositis may be associated with internal malignancy. Ovarian carcinoma more frequently occurs in association with dermatomyositis than the other choices. The skin signs that are shown in the photographs include 1) periungual erythema, nail fold telangiectasia,and cuticle dystrophy; 2) holster sign; 3) pruritic, violaceous erythema of scalp; 4) violaceous erythema of extensor surfaces and shawl sign; and 5) Gottron papules and linear streaking. These physical signs in association with the classic heliotrope rash and edema of the eyelids help to prompt diagnosis of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman complains of a 3-week history of palpitations and shakiness. She attributes her insomnia to her new baby, born 5 weeks previously. On examination there is increased sweating, a fine tremor of outstretched hands, and a small non tender goiter. Laboratory investigations show TSH < 0.002mIU/L and free thyroxine 2.1 ng/dL (0.8-1.8). She is breastfeeding. Which one of the following investigations is indicatedto help establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The differential diagnosis includes Graves disease and postpartum thyroiditis. Radioactive iodine uptake is elevated in the former and suppressed in the latter. However, this investigation is contraindicated in this setting because radioactive iodine is excreted in breast milk and may cause permanent hypothyroidism in the child. The ESR and TBG level may be elevated in thyroiditis and Graves disease. TSH receptor antibodies are likely to be present in Graves disease (>98% specificity; 90% sensitivity).

choices.text: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection withMycobacteriumavium-intracellulare complex (MAC) of the small bowel

questions.text: A 70-year-old man complains of diarrhea and four episodes of arthritis over the past 3 months. His family thinks he is becoming more forgetful. On examination, he appears hyperpigmented and has generalized lymphadenopathy. Fecal fat is 20 g/24 h.Small-bowel biopsy specimens show periodic acid-Schiff(PAS)–positive/acid-fast–negative granules in macrophages in lamina propria of the small intestine. The most likely cause of this patient’s illness is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Patients with Whipple disease (caused by the bacterium Tropherymawhippelii) may have PAS-positive granules in small-bowel biopsy specimens. MACis also a PAS-positive organism that resembles T.whippelii. MAC, however, is an acid-fastpositive organism and T. whippelii is not. The diagnosis of Whipple disease is confirmed by use of a polymerase chain reaction test, which detects the organism in small-bowel biopsy material.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to your office for a routine annual examination. His history is significant for 7 years of mild ulcerative colitis that has been well controlled with mesalamine alone. He has no family history of colon cancer or polyps. Thepatient is at increased risk of each of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
All the factors listed are associated with higher risk in patients with ulcerative colitis except oxalate kidney stones, which occur in patients with Crohn disease after extensive terminal ileum resection and subsequent bile acid pool depletion and steatorrhea. Free fatty acids in the stool bind to calcium, thus freeing up dietary oxalate to be absorbed in excess.

questions.text: At an annual examination, a 58-year-old asymptomatic woman has elevated liver enzymes. She has a history of diabetes mellitus, for which she uses metformin. She drinks one small glass of wine daily but denies prior blood transfusions,needlestick exposures, illicit drug use, and family history of liver disease. Physical examination findings are notable for a body mass index of 38 kg/m2. Laboratory tests are notable for ALT 84 U/L, AST 63 U/L, glycosylated hemoglobin 5.3%, low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol 180 mg/dL,and triglycerides 240 mg/dL. Antihepatitis C virus (HCV),hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), and serum iron study results are negative or normal. Antinuclear antibody (ANA)is positive at a titer of 1:40, antismooth muscle antibody is negative, and -globulin is 1.0 g/dL. Ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant is notable for changes in liver echotexture consistent with fat and gallbladder stones without gallbladder wall thickening. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The patient most likely has NAFL disease, which is a common cause of abnormal liver test results. NAFL is associated with obesity,diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Although prevalence figures vary,probably 20% of obese patients and 2% of lean patients have NAFL.Nonalcoholicsteatohepatitis (NASH), a subset of NAFL, is characterized by the histologic finding of macrovesicular fatty degener-ation with inflammation in a patient with negligible ethanol intake.Most patients have modest elevations in levels of aminotransferases and, occasionally, alkaline phosphatase. Bilirubin, albumin, and prothrombin time are usually normal unless decompensated cirrhosis is present. Metformin only rarely causes liver hepatotoxicity and would be much less likely than a common disorder such as NAFL.
Alcoholic hepatitis requires about 40 g/d of alcohol intake and would usually produce a more prominent elevation in the level of ASTthan of ALT. The patient has gallbladder stones but is asymptomatic and therefore does not have cholecystitis. The patient has a low-titer positive ANA, raising the possibility of autoimmune hepatitis;however, autoimmune hepatitis is usually characterized by higher levels of aminotransferases, higher titers of autoantibodies, and anelevated -globulin level.

choices.text: Assure him this is impossible because fragile X is inherited as an X-linked trait.
Assure him this is impossible because he is of normal intelligence.
Assure him his symptoms are related to stress.
Order a molecular analysis for fragile X.

questions.text: A 60-year-old veterinarian states that he is stressed because his grandson has mental retardation due to fragile X syndrome and will be moving to a group home. The man has noted a tremor and problems with his memory and is concerned that this may be related to the fragile X syndrome in his family.What do you do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Molecular testing will show his CAG repeat size for this gene and determine whether he is a permutation carrier who is at risk for neurologic degeneration. Chromosome analysis may, but more likely will not show a fragile site in a permutation carrier.
